comments.author: DoeEyedDeer

comments.text:
I think the creators of the wiz were sending a message in a way. It was 
almost like they were making a statement when these sweatshop workers 
(slaves) unzipped their costumes that they were made to wear and they came 
out as beautiful people and they were free. It's almost as if it were a 
metaphor saying especially to the African American community that we are 
beautiful people underneath these ugly costumes that society has placed on 
us. Sadly alot of people haven't gotten the message, they merely just see a 
movie. Some people are still trapped in their costumes today.﻿
comments.author: Jadon Carter

comments.text: True that!
comments.author: samiegrrl

comments.text: +Jamar Carr You need an award.
comments.author: Sara Miller

comments.text:
+Jamar Carr I think you are right that's EXACTLY the message the the 
creators were trying to send! I agree with you 100%! NBC is going to make 
this their next live musical! Which hopefully will help send some important 
messages to a lot of people in the Country that need to hear them! And 
frankly I hope they do better with the Wiz than they did Peter Pan and the 
Sound of Music! The Wiz though has so much more meaning and takes much more 
of a stance than these other shows (not to mention just being better all 
the way around) so it would be hard NOT to do better with it! (knock on 
wood!!!)

comments.text:
Michael really was the perfect choice for the role of Scarecrow! He's got 
the whole carefree, rubber-legs schick going down!  When I watched this as 
a kid, I had no idea it was Michael Jackson playing that role, since all I 
knew of him was his 90's face and music at the time.  Rewatched it years 
later and had to look up who played Scarecrow because I recognized the 
singing voice but couldn't believe it was him.  Apparently, I had my head 
stuck in the sand until about 18....ugh.  ﻿

comments.author: BlessedAngelDiamond

comments.text:
To me, this is a great example of multiculturalism.  I'm as white as they 
get.  I grew up on the "Wizard of Oz."  My kids have seen that movie.  The 
one I show them now is "The Wiz."  Why?  Because, to me, it celebrates 
everything.  Can you feel it?  I can.﻿
comments.author: KidIndigo1

comments.text:
How can you call it multiculturalism when the cast is all black?

It's about as "multicultural" as the MGM "Wizard"-- less so, really, seeing 
as the MGM movie had over 100 members of a "minority" in it, namely midgets.

"The Wiz" is a magnificent movie, with a wonderful cast and probably the 
best soundtrack ever recorded for a musical. But multicultural it ain't, 
and it wasn't meant to be.
comments.author: MaskedMan66

comments.text:
Can you feel it? It's a brand new day!! Every day is a blessing, because 
it's a new day to be better than you were yesterday.  If yesterday wasn't 
the best, if you had some downfall, some disappointment, if you weren't 
thankful, or if you didn't pray for someone else yesterday, today is a new 
day. Be thankful, be blessed and be a blessing. ﻿
comments.author: Aminta Gatling

comments.text: My favorite part of the movie! It's so uplifting﻿
comments.author: RedSimba

comments.text:
Aww, it doesn't have the part where they come out of the ugly suits. Anyway 
love this song, Love The Wiz. My kids have seen this over dozen of times. I 
remember seeing this on late night tv back in the early nineties. Before we 
had cable at our house. Fox was like the only channel that stayed on all 
night back then. I was in awe, it was the first black movie that I saw was 
all black and was like the Wizard of Oz. I was in love with this movie but 
did not see it again for many years. Then I went on a hunt and found and 
when I had kids made sure they see black musicals and movies where there 
are people that look like them. There should be more positive movies, 
actors, roles models, etc out there for children see doing positive things,﻿
comments.author: SouthernBeautie2010

comments.author: MaskedMan66

comments.text:
I met Diana Ross at the airport about two years ago and she couldn't have 
been nicer. The whole time I was thinking why does this woman have such a 
bad reputation. I guess people who have never met her just like to put her 
down for no apparent reason other than "well I HEARD someone say she is a 
witch". But I DID meet her and she couldn't be lovelier.﻿
comments.author: BujoldComa78

comments.text:
It's a combination of things. Diana is from the ghetto, but has always 
acted like she's from The Hamptons . Diana frustrated many, because she had 
this squeaky, squealing voice that got all the record sales, and was who 
others were compared to. She didn't have an R and B voice, yet that turned 
out to be a plus. She was thin, glamourous, eloquent, radiated charisma, 
class like no other..  No other black star could touch her. Not then, not 
now. Beyonce?  Please. No, no and no.

People like to hate on greatness, because they don't have it and it gets 
all the attention, meanwhile they flounder in obscurity
comments.author: BroccoliBeefed

comments.text:
Because people have a problem with classy, glamourous, goal oriented, 
ambitious, black women . It's called jealousy.  There are those that say 
she slept to the top or stepped on people to get to the top. Well. who 
hasn't done that to get to the top?  The notion that people buy music based 
on who fucked who is just asinine

I've met her too --she was nice.. I don't care what people say about Diana 
Ross. They're just jealous.
comments.author: BroccoliBeefed

comments.text:
I have to say this Nipsey Russell who played the Tin Man in this film was 
60 years old when he made this movie. That man could dance very well for a 
man whose first profession wasn't dancing. Nipsey Russell was a comedian 
and poet first. Man a 60 year old man who is a comedian and poet dancing 
with people like Diana Ross and Michael Jackson who were known for dancing 
as well as singing and who were 26 and 40 years his junior is very 
impressive!!!!! You should watch his dancing scene in this movie when The 
Tin Man was first introduced. His tapping was superb!!!! I never would've 
guessed he was 60 years old when he made this film!!!!!!!!!﻿
